content:
Nice one, but none of the test cases have a "40" number in them that requires "XL" in the output. Would be good to add one.

I got 87% in a clash because I'd missed this issue.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Challengeant, même si il en existe déjà quelques uns de ce type

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The description is clear and easy for beginners to try solving this puzzle.

I was able to code this in about 6 minutes, but I also know the trick. Someone who has forgotten how Roman numerals work would have to actually read all that text, and might still not see a shortcut.

If you want to leave it as a clash, then you're going to have to provide a lot more help to the programmer. Here is the table that makes this easier to solve, poorly formatted:

____________ 1 _ 2 _ 3 _ 4 _ 5 _ 6 _ 7 _ 8 _ 9
100's place: C CC CCC CD D DC DCC DCCC CM
Ten's place: X XX XXX XL L LX LXX LXXX XL
One's place: I II III IV V VI VII VIII IX

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Easy to understand and solution as well

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: I recommend to make it as an easy puzzle and not as a clash

Maybe better for an easy puzzle instead of a clash. I personally solved it in about 10 minutes but, doing so, I couldn't remove from my thoughts your solution with the mapping of roman numbers for 900, 400, 90, 40, 9 and 4, which facilitate the search for answer but may not come in mind that fast during a clash.

I like the idea but I think this may be a bit too hard. It took me 15 minutes and I've been programming in Python off and on for 20 years. (Admittedly I'm pretty tired at the moment so I might typically finsih this in 7-8 minutes.) I'm sure there's some easier way to do it, but I think most programmers will struggle to do this in less than 15 minutes. Also it looks like there's an error in the last few words of instruction 7.

I'm curious if others can solve it more quickly.

Hello,

Test 8 and Validator 8 should be swapped. So that the validators are all consistent with their tests

Goal
* Please format "NONE" as a {{constant}} and remove the quotation marks.

* Please explain how other decimal numbers not in your list should be represented.

Input / Output / Constraints
* Please format "n" as a [[variable]].

Output
* Please add "or {{NONE}}".

Thanks.
I like it, but aren't validator cases supposed to be different from tests?
Ah, I see. This is my first time trying to contribute. Thanks for the feedback, I'll change the test case for validator.
Thank you for the input, I don't really know about text formatting, I have updated it.
Yes, I think this is good idea in term of consistency. Thanks
That's makes sense. I'll consider to make it easy puzzle instead of clash as @Eckerdecker recommended as well. Thank you for your input.

When creating this puzzle, I already had that solution in mind, so maybe I can think faster, but yeah, maybe for others won't be the same. I'm considering your suggestion to change it into easy puzzle instead fo clash. Thanks mate.
There are existing Roman numeral puzzles already. I don't think converting the current clash into a puzzle is a good idea, unless you have some interesting ideas to add to the contribution.
The other option is to give the player more help as David Augusto Villa suggested, if you prefer to keep at as a Clash. They are both good options.
Another small adjustment ... The validators for tests 7 and 8 are identical with their tests. They should be different if possible.

No worries.

Please don't just state "Note: You need to figure out all other roman numbers". Please EXPLAIN the relevant rules. Thanks.

How do you think I should EXPLAIN it? Roman number is roman number, should I write down all the roman number from 1 - 3999? If that's the case, we can just solve using if else from 1 - 3999. If you have any idea, please elaborate more or you can give me an example. 

In my opinion I think it's pretty clear on my side, which input is integer decimal between 0 - 3999, and output is roman number, the guidelines is just to help them. Maybe I should put a URL to a wikipedia or something that explain about roman number? Thanks

The contribution guidelines mention:

"CoC statements should be self-sufficient.

When your time is counted, as a player, you don't want to waste time searching for a formula or a definition online to understand what needs to be done."

Link for your reference: https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/contribution-guidelines

Your statement won't be clear to somebody who doesn't know how to convert decimal numbers to Roman numerals. For example, they won't know how to convert 4: it'll be IIII based on your guideline. Nor will they know how to convert 6: is it VI or IV? (I know the answer, but not all the players do.)

You may refer to this statement as an example when adding an explanation:
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/7890e6b4f46c9e8890f896dda481f1860d76

Thanks.

Thanks again I've updated it, but not sure if this is clear enough.
Apparently there is same puzzle, maybe I need to create the reverse version from Roman number to decimal.

I think it's clear enough. Thanks.

Your puzzle is almost the same as that other puzzle. I'm not rejecting yours because your clash requires the additional handling of 0 as input.
Thanks mate. Yes, because Roman number don't have zero or negative number handling, so we need to handle that as well. I'll create the reverse version Roman number to decimal number later.

I didn't notice at first sight, you set the puzzle to be a reversed one, maybe in that case validators and tests are supposed to be the same.
I never contributed myself, and started to comment yesterday, so I don't really know.
Tests should always be different from validators, except for edge cases. The mode does not matter.
